description.text: Pieces to allow permanent mounting of TrackIR reflector to a baseball cap with a couple of screws.

Filament spool holder for a Tiko, designed to fit in Tiko's spool holder cavity and work with standard spool sizes. There are two versions, the smaller version 84mm is pictured. This one was designed to be small enough to be printable on a Tiko, but large enough to work the the spool that comes with the Tiko. The larger version should work with the widest spools that I've seen (here's a list of spool dimensions - http://thrinter.com/empty-spool-weights/). You can also modify the design on Onshape

I find that most spool holder in this style work well until the spools are almost empty. When the filament is running out, especially with the lighter spools, the pull of the filament can knock the spool off the bearings. Usually the spool is light enough at that point that nothing bad happens, but it's worth keeping in mind if you use this spool holder.

Parts:
Assembly requires some M5 screws, M5 washers, bearings, and ball-end hex wrenches. You can use different combinations of bearing sizes to match the filament spools you're using. Use the washers to prevent the bearings from binding on other parts.

  • socket cap M5 screws and washers - the exact length will depend on your configuration but I used 30mm screws.
  • 5x16x5mm bearings - amazon link*, banggood link*
  • 5x14x5mm bearings - amazon link*, banggood link*
  • ball end hex wrenches* - ball-end hex wrenches make it easier to screw in the screws at an angle.
  • glue dots* (optional) - I use a few of these to keep the spool holder in place.

Misc:

  • The Tiko spool and an Atomic Filament spool are in the pictures.
  • I find 16mm bearings on the outside for the Tiko spool with 14mm bearings on inside seems good for most of the spools I use regularly, but haven't done much testing.
  • Use small washers between the plastic and bearings to keep them from binding.
  • There are some large printable washers to help align smaller spools, but I haven't needed them yet.
  • When spools are running low, they may not have enough weight to stay on the bearings.
  • This is a work in progress, and has not been tested very thoroughly and may change.

Printer:
-- Eustathios

Filaments:
-- Atomic Filament Transparent Red PLA

*affiliate links

title: Adjustable X Endstop for GeeeTech Prusa I3 Pro B

description.text:
This is a simple adjustable endstop for the GeeeTech Prusa I3 Pro B.

It is designed to slip over the existing aluminium XCarriage endstop trigger nub and allows you to fine tune the home position of the extruder in the X axis.

Printer:

GeeeTech Prusa I3 Pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.02mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PLA 40mm/s at 215 degrees.

Required Parts

1 x Printed Model
1 x M3 X 40mm Bolt
1 x Spring (Same as used for heatbed and Z endstop)
1 x M3 x 8mm Bolt
2 x M3 Square Nut
3 x M3 Washer

Step 1 - Prepare the new endstop

Take the 40mm bolt and thread the following onto it in the order written:
M3 Washer
Spring
M3 Washer

Take a square nut and slot it into the rear slot (the one that cuts through the whole model).
Screw the 40mm bolt and the spring/washers into the long hole that intersects with the square nut. The end of the bold should protrude out of the back of the model, this is what will trigger the microswitch.

Step 2 - Remove the extruder

In order to have enough room to use tools around the X carriage it is required for you to remove the extruder from the carriage.

This can be done by removing the two bolts from the underside of the extruder.
It should then just lift off of the carriage.

Put the extruder somewhere to the side, out of the way for the time being.

If needed disconnect any cables and remove the filament (I managed to get by without doing this).

Step 3 - Attaching the new endstop

Now that you have some room to work you can begin to attach the new endstop.

Take a square nut and slot it into the remaining slot on the underside of the model.

Note: I found it helpful to put some tape over the nut to stop it falling out while I was attaching the endstop. (Should have put the slot on the top)

Take the endstop and slot it over the X carriage lining the holes in the model and the X carriage (if possible).

Take the remaining 8mm bolt and thread the washer onto it.

Slot the bolt into the model and re-position the model until the bolt goes through the hole in the X carriage. Tighten down the bolt until the model will not move.

Remove any tape if you used it.

Note: I had to position the model at a slight angle so that the 40mm bolt did not catch on the mount bolt for the X carriage.

Step 4 - Reattach the extruder

This process is simply the reverse of step 2. Place the extruder back onto the X carriage and tighten down to two bolts.

Reattach any cables you removed in step 2.

Step 5 - Configuring

With steppers disabled or the printer off:

Slide the X carriage to the home position (the position where your nozzle is at its left most limit of the printable area).

Tighten the 40mm bolt until it engages the microswitch, you should hear a click.

If your firmware supports it you maybe able to get a visual readout on the LCD when the endstop is engaged. This significantly helps in configuring the endstop.

As a test home the X axis and ensure that the nozzle is in the correct position afterwards. If not repeat the instructions for this step again until you have got the configuration how you would like it.

Congratulations

Your new adjustable X endstop is good to go.

Why this was needed for my printer.

As the extruder tensioner that comes with the GeeeTech I3 Pro B is a bit lacking (no adjustable tension/made of plastic) I decided to upgrade to an all aluminium alternative. Unfortunately I could only get it in a left hand configuration. After modifying the extruder to be mirrored I realised that the existing endstop trigger nub on the X carriage would not reach the endstop microswitch.

To fix this I designed this adjustable add-on for the X carriage using OpenSCAD and spare parts from the printer build.

author: jtrantow

title: 20mm Diameter Ball Mold (for slingshot ammo)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I love slingshots. But the challenge is having uniform ammo to shoot. Marbles are cheap but they leave broken glass everywhere. Steel shot (ball bearings) is not cheap, but with a magnet you can retrieve your ammo. But I'd rather not. So what I need is some biodegradable disposable ammo that is sufficiently dense enough to take down a jackrabbit. So eventually my plan is to make a metal mold which can be heated. Then I was going to take my PLA rafts and powder them in a blender, then mix the powder with sawdust from the woodshop, then compress that mixture with a hydraulic press into my heated metal mold.

But in the mean time, there is an RTV mold making class and a carbon fiber class every other week at the local TechShop. They always have left over RTV or resin after the class. So I made this mold to utilize the usually wasted material. The RTV balls hurt like a son-of-a-gun and leave a nice little bruise on my intended victims.

Personally I like 20mm diameter spherical ammo for my slingshot ammo. I have big hands and ammo smaller than 15mm is a pain for me. Plus there just isn't enough mass to hunt anything significant. So I tend to make ammo about in 15mm-20mm diameter spheres.

I designed this mold on TinkerCad, because it's so easy to use I can get my ideas out faster and easier than in a parametric cad/cam program. Here's the link to the files;

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4izNkjRnmsV-20mm-ball-mold/editv2?sharecode=wQqav2OqwpUzCW_hGllUokjeetJ9BiTrGIkQpWCfYH8=

So you will need to print two of these mold pieces. They should mesh perfectly together. Eventually I'm going to add a luer lock directly into the mold so that you can take a syringe full of material and connect it to the mold and inject away.

comments.text: If you made the mold out of abs or pet you could buy oven curing clay from any craft store as your ammo. The mold may eventually warp though.

description.text:
I made this handle to make it easier to pickup my HyperCube Printer (CoreXY). The handle is narrower than commercial units that look similar so it fits on 2020 aluminum extrusions. The two mounting holes allow 5 mm screws and a 2020 fastener to attach the handle to the printer. This handle can also be used as a general purpose handle for any equipment. The strength of this handle is greatly dependent on your printing material and parameters so be careful picking your parameters so that your handle can lift your object.

For my 3D printer I printed the handle in ABS which I suggest for strength and resistance to cracks. I printed the handle with 70% infill to make sure that it is very solid. You must use supports for the screw pockets.

title: 3 point bed holder for tehnologika.net y-carriage

description.text:
3-point plate (hot bed, glass, alu plate...) holder for Y-carriage from:
TEHNOLOGIKA

why? - I'm not using the aluminium plate at all because have a piece of borosilicate glass that has heater glued directly on it so no screws in/trough glass/heater so something like this is required. As you can see in one of the pictures, you can use your original heated pcb bed (with or without glass on top of it) with this 3 point system too.

update 20170107:

  • shorter shaft so a thumbscrew can be used
  • seating for the spring
  • longer lip to hold narrower glass too
  • mount works great, fits perfectly, holds the bed nicely, no play!
  • the only thing left to test is how strong the ABS will be holding 110C bed inside 70C chamber

update 20170108:

  • added 3 new versions of bed piece, original one expect M4x5x5mm metal insert to be pushfitted into the hole on top so that M4 screw can be used to clamp the glass cap to the bed piece. Since not everyone have these metal inserts 3 other versions are added, one with a small 2mm hole that will properly hold a 3mm plastic (or wood) screw and a version with 3mm hole trough it and M3 nut holder on the bottom of the shaft so one can use M3 screw and nut to hold the glass cap and one with M4 hole and place for a trap M4 nut (probably best version if you are not using inserts)
  • added second glass cap with thicker end if you want to hold in bed something that's thinner then 4mm (like for e.g. 3mm plate)
  • tested the whole contraption in real life, no play, ABS is not deforming while heated bed is at 110C and chamber at 70C

update 20130309:
I was using 35mm M3 screws (to go trough "bed piece" and the bed) with round Socket Cap head and they tend to rotate inside the piece sometimes so bed leveling gets harder then it should so I found the hexagon head bolts M3x35mm on blej and redesigned the bed piece to take the hex head m3 there so it would not rotate :)

Printer:

self made

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15-0.25

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The parts are strongest the way they are laid down in STL, unfortunately this means for the "8mm shaft" piece you need to use support.

I'm using ABS as material to print this, I'm pretty sure PLA will not work (as the parts will deform when bed goes over 60C), dunno how PC, HIPS or Nylon would perform

1. attach a "carriage piece" to your tehnologika bed so that the hole in the piece aligns with the hole in the bed
  2. add a spring over the hole (use the original springs that came with M150's bed), it should snap comfortably into the "seat" over the hole
  3. select your "bed piece" depending on how do you plan to attach glas cap to it, and place it in the carriage piece, the spring should seat in the bed piece too
  4. put the M3 screw, min length 25mm, max length 35mm (ideal 30mm) trough both pieces
  5. screw in the m3 on the bottom of the carriage piece (or use those thumb nuts that came with M150 or print one of the thumb nuts from the thingiverse)
  6. add a glass cap (if your bed is thicker then 4mm use flat glass cap piece, if your bed is 4mm or thinner use the "glass cap thinner bed" piece) and fasten to the bed piece using the selected way of fastening (if you are using metal insert use M4 screw, if you are using self tapping screws or m3 screw use those..), fasten loose so you can move the glass cap out of the way so you can put your bed in (and later tighten the cap)

repeat three times

Optionally, when everything is done, you can "fix" the M3 screw going trough everything. In this design I'm using "round" head seat for the M3 screws (cause I only have this type of M3's) and in this case only friction is holding the M3 screw from turning when you tighten/loosen the nut on the bottom. There's 2 way of fixing the M3 screw:

  • if your screw have threads all trough then you can just use a nut (ideally nyloc) and secure the M3 screw in place. The spring will go neatly over the nut so no worries there.
  • if your screw don't have threads all the way (most long one don't) then, what I did, is mix some ABS waste with some acetone to get a thick mixture (very thick, like paste / clay) and fill the top hole where the M3 head is completely while M3 head is in; leave for 24 hours to completely dry and solidify.. the M3 will be tightly secured and will not self rotate :D

Anyhow, even without "fixing" the M3 screw, you only need to hold it by hand while fastening the bottom nut for the first time, once you tighten the spring the friction will be enough to hold it in place and not allow it to rotate

ONSHAPE

designed using onshape, source available here (if you create account on onshape you can also edit/copy/export the parts):

bed holder source on ONSHAPE

comments.text: Hi, I found your idea very intriguing as I would love to get rid of my heavy aluminum heat bed.
comments.author: TpAurora

comments.text: It all depends on the heater. This heater works ok (I also have a thermal camera and the glass is very evenly heated :D ) so with this heater I have this works flawlessly and temp differences over the glass are under 1C... so that's not a problem. There is a whole other problem with only heater+glass and that's "you want to remove the glass to clean it" and it's a bitch to remove it when it's setup like this.
comments.author: TpAurora

comments.text: Mind sharing the image from your thermal camera? Thats great to hear it works with just glass.
comments.author: BogdanKecman

comments.text: hm .. interesting, I can't find original images but I know the difference was +-1C around the entire glass .. that was ~year ago .. today I'm imaging same thing with same camera and .. well it's more then +-5C .. it still works ok for ABS, no lifting, no visible issues but it's definitely showing differences.. I assume it's due to glue between glass and heater or due to glass changing properties... who knows :D
comments.author: TpAurora

comments.text: hey thanks a lot for taking a pic! i wish I had a thermal imaging camera lol. interesting results.
comments.author: BogdanKecman

comments.text: they are not that expensive these days.. considering how much $$$ we spend on printers camera is cheap :D
comments.author: TpAurora

comments.text: I'll see if I have it around still if not I'll snap new one... anyhow, glass itself won't spread heat as is well known so it depends highly on the heater. In my case 500W keenovo 220VAC heater. The glass is evenly heated only 'cause heater is evenly getting hot, any unevenness of the heater you'd see amplified on the glass...
comments.author: TpAurora

comments.text:
Btw. if you use an ABL Probe with the mount from hoolyhoo you need to adjust the firmware so it doesn't press into the holder clips.

description.text:
This is a bike mount for a Garmin 920XT GPS watch. It's designed to fit to a 1" diameter handle bar with no tools or additional hardware. There is the provision for tie wraps if you wanted to install them. This will work with any watch. What makes it unique for the 920XT is that the rib is designed to keep the watchband from scooting off the mount. If your watchband is 1.08" or less it will fit in the groove, and won't slide out.

The 7/8" version of this is thing 2019868

This is a calliper adapter that allow its use by people with hand movement problems (this was designed for a patient that has lost his thumb)

(The adapter design must be changed depending on the calliper shape.)

comments.text:
Very cool model. I printed one for use on a Modulus Recon MkII, and it works with a couple modifications:
1) The tactical rail on the top of the MkII is slightly elevated compared to the original Recon. As a result, the screw holes in the handle need to be about 8mm lower than in this model. I just drilled out new holes.
2) The slide ('top' model) needs to be mounted slightly offset from where the top hole is. I just drilled an extra hole in the top at the location where the pump had enough range to fully prime the gun.

description.text:
This model was inspired by a similar one by CloudJ and an article regarding the "Perfect Snowman". I've linked to both below. I went through a couple of iterations before settling on this one. The mold is symmetrical, so you'll need to print two, but you can fit both on a 200x200mm platform easily. I've included an STL file with 2 halves. I've also uploaded the Fusion 360 file so you can change things as you'd like.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675620
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3404856/Formula-perfect-snowman-Use-three-balls-fresh-snow-make-64-inches-tall-carrot-nose-1-5-inches-long.html

Update 1/10/2017: Finally got enough of the right kind of snow to give these a try. They work great, but there are a few minor changes I'd like to implement. The first and main one are the keys. They work, but they get filled with snow immediately which gets turned into ice with the pressure exerted. I'm thinking I will move them to the sides where only half the sphere would be in the model so the snow can just fall out when you are putting the two halves together.

description.text: This is a two part crayon mold. The two mold halves snap together, and can be held with a rubber band or two. Heat crayon bits and pour into mold. Let cool, tap the mold a few times gently and pull apart. For best results use nail polish remover to make crayon cavities nice and smooth to make for better extraction of crayons. See .pdf for full step by step instructions.

Smooth crayon cavities

I used rubber gloves, nail polish remover and cotton swabs/paper towels. Simply rub some nail polish remover back and fourth in the cavities. I used the rubber gloves to keep the nail polish remover away from my fingers/nails. Once I was done I rinsed with tap water and dried.

This is an update of the Old School Space Rocket, based on comments from Bre after he cut and build the first physical copy. Change log:
  • Made the spines that run the length of the hull twice as thick, for structural support and for aesthetics.
  • Re-made the ribs that define the cross-section of the hull from scratch with circular voids and fine-tuned dimensions for aesthetics and better fit.
  • Hollowed out the legs for aesthetics.
  • Re-made the feet using the same spine & rib method as the hull, for consistency, for the challenge, for aesthetics, and for the win!
  • Re-arranged the pieces on the cutting pattern so that you could cut from two rectangles instead of a single square.

Same as the old version, cut this from either a 12"x12" square of 1/8" acrylic for the 15" version, or if you believe bigger is better, from two 12"x24" rectangles of 1/4" acrylic for the 30" version. (Guess which version I want)
Assembly should be straightforward with the help of a hot glue gun. Cyanoacrylate probably could use some roughing up of the contact surfaces, say with sand-paper. 
If a rib has three slots, it belongs in the upper part of the hull. 
If it has four slots, it belongs in the feet. These ribs should be attached to the leg, then the foot closed with the short length of spine, and lastly the curved spines should attach on the sides. Sounds complicated but with the parts in hand it should be obvious. I'll include an exploded view in the images as well.
If it has six slots, it belongs in the lower part of the hull where the legs attach.
Good luck and don't hesitate to comment if you are having issues with this design.

description.text: The data for this STL is taken from a micro-CT scan of a mouse skull, processed in ImageJ - http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/ . The original data was provided by Mark Henkelman of the Mouse Imaging Centre (MICe) http://www.mouseimaging.ca Files include the whole skull, and then a left half-skull sliced just to the left of the midline. I made this one as I was interested in the structure of the turbinate bones in the nasal passages, and it can be tricky to visualize complex 3D structures like this on a computer screen, even with 3D rendering. Note that this is downsampled from the original micro-CT image as ImageJ was not able to cope with converting the full file to an STL on my computer. I will also try to upload the 160 Mb 3D TIFF file containing the full scan. The internal detail visible in this file is amazing (sequential images scan from the tip of the nose through the back of the head). Photos show the half skull printed on a Stratasys FDM machine (black) and an Objet 24 (white). The FDM print is scaled up by an additional factor of two due to resolution limitations. UPDATE 2012.10.15: Uploaded a demo print of the model done on the Zcorp ZPrinter 450 (same size as the black ABS one). The colour is arbitrary, I put it in to test the printer's colour capabilities. UPDATE 2013.04.06: Uploaded a demo print of the model done on the Replicator2 (red, same size as the black ABS one). Quality on surfaces where I had to remove support / raft is only marginally inferior (if anything) to the Stratasys machine using soluble support, surfaces that did not require support are equivalent.

title: Adjustable tablet holder for DJI Mavic PRO

description.text:
Version

Last updated: 7th March 2017

About

I designed this holder because I needed one for my iPad Air.
The basic idea was born when I saw "Foldable Tablet Holder for DJI MAVIC Ver.2" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982834).
The only thing I missed was that holder from Banggood - so I made my own.
My tabled holder is adjustable from 130 to 185mm (or 108 to 166mm when smaller stopper is used), so it can hold iPad Air and iPad mini too (and other great tablets and phones as well).

Requirements

Already printed Base and LockKey of this item: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982834/
1pcs M4x12mm HEX-head screw
1pcs M5x25mm screw
1pcs M4 nut
1pcs M5 nut
1pcs M3x20mm screw
1pcs M3x10mm screw
2pcs M3 nut
4pcs woodscrew 2.5x20mm

Printer:

Poseidon DUO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

80%

Notes:

Print ideally from PLA:
1pcs base.STL

1pcs screwhead.STL
1pcs arm.STL
1pcs arm_mirrored.STL
2pcs stopper.STL
"OR"

(this depends on thickness of your device when using protective case)
"OR"

(this is version for devices smaller devices from 108-166mm)

title: Nirwen's Mercy- Destiny Legendary Pulse Rifle

description.text:
Nirwen's Mercy, the legendary pulse rifle that was a mainstay of year 2 crucible.

I always wanted this so decided to get a file sorted by someone on shapeways.com and print out the gun for myself. Once I've done my basking in the worlds first 3d printed Nirwen's I thought I'd make it available for everyone!

Once built (I used cheap epoxy resin to glue it all together) it's pretty solid and should be able to stand up to light cosplay, mines going on the wall.

I hope all the files work, they didn't need much manipulation on my end, mostly separating of the barrel shrouds and rotating as they're very tricky to print in the vertical position. If you have any questions I'll try my best to help......but no promises.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jnr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Originally obtained from Destinystlgenerator.com the files were then fixed to be printable and split to be able to fit onto a 6" cubed print bed that the Da Vinci Jnr has. I didn't do the file fixing so can't really help you have any major problems with them.

If you have a larger print bed, or are prepared to manipulate the models some what, you could join a few of the parts together and print fewer overall parts.

Some manipulation and thought it needed when assembling, I had a little trouble and had to fudge it in a couple of places.

title: Changed base for the Lite Arm i2 & S3 robot adapter

description.text:
This is a changed base for the Lite Arm i2. The original thing is the "Open Source Robotic Arm (Lite Arm i2) " http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480446
The external appearance of the arm is the same. However I made the base stronger and simpler (two parts less)

I changed some parts from the base of the Arm and I replaced some others with one part. I also replace the bearing with another stronger.
More specifically :
1) I changed the original part 1B.stl to the 1B_NEW.stl
2) I changed the original part 5B.stl to the 5B_NEW.stl
3) I replaced the original three parts 2B.stl, 3B.stl and 4B.stl with one part the 2_3_4_B_NEW.stl

Last but not least , I added two small accessories in order to adapt the arm on the Parallax S3 robot. S3_I2Arm_adapter_bottom.stl and S3_I2Arm_adapter_top.stl

Note:
If you have the original (Lite Arm i2) and you want to adapt it on to S3 robot, you don't need to change the base. The only you need is the two adapters S3_I2Arm_adapter_bottom.stl and S3_I2Arm_adapter_top.stl

author: Adonfff

print_settings.Notes:: Good luck, happy printing, and leave a comment if you have any questions.

description.text:
Superceeded by v2 at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2157448

This is a series of upgrades for the Geeetech G2s printer. The stock unit has a number of design issues that I wanted to address to get better prints.

The upgrades are printable parts, to be used with some sourced components.

I've included the master assembly as both STEP and native Fusion360.
Before printing, consider calibrating/compensating for material shrinkage. I've made a utility at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1982686 to assist in this - but use whatever method works for you.

  1. New Carriages.
    The stock carriages use 2 cheaper bearings. The short contact length and slop results in a significant amount of play when the effector changes direction, putting torque on the carriage. In my case, I found this to be up to .300mm as measured by a good quality dial indicator when near to the towers. These new carriages show under .02mm deviation.
    These new carriages use 2 additional linear bearings. I used some Misumi LMU-N10 that I ordered from their website at https://us.misumi-ec.com/vona2/detail/110300026540/?HissuCode=LMU-N10. The carriages are designed to accept metal spheres with M3 studs, like the ones provided in the Magnetic arm kit (listed below).
  2. Magnetic arms.
    The stock rod ends have 2 issues. First, they can't be exactly calibrated to the same length, due to the manufacture of the threads on the rod and rod ends (in my set anyway). I managed to get them close, but I wanted better. The rod ends also are fairly cheap, and it showed in the precision. I managed to get most of the slop out by center-punching the casing, but wasn't happy with these either.
    I decided to go with good magnetic arms:
    http://www.blueeaglelabs.com/products/haydns-carbon-fiber-arms-with-cnc-precision-machined-delrin-sockets
    These have excellent holding power, are very accurately calibrated, and the metal spheres ride in machined Delrin sockets (spheres included).
    I chose the 215mm length, which works perfectly for the G2s.
  3. Effector and hotend.
    The Mk8 hotend was a pain to adjust the nozzles level, and limited the usable bed on an already small machine. I still wanted dual extrusion though, so I went with an E3D Cyclops: http://e3d-online.com/Cyclops. I added to this a 50mm blower fan for part cooling, as the stock unit is lacking this - a must as far as i'm concerned.
  4. Extruder.
    The Cyclops hotend requires more force than the stock direct extruder can put out. I ordered 2 of the Greg's Wade Extruder hardware kit at https://www.ultibots.com/gregs-wade-extruder-hardware-kit/, and printed 2 sets of the extruder parts - 1 regular and 1 mirrored: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379.
    In order to fit in the location of the original, you need to mirror one of the extruders. In doing so you need to reverse the hobbed bolt - to get the hobbed portion of the bolt aligned with the feeder tube, you'll need the attached spacer. In addition, the attached gear has a deeper relief to accept the bolt in the mirrored extruder.
  5. FSR probing.
    I wanted a probe, but couldn't decide on inductive, capacitive, BLtouch, etc. Some work with glass, some don't... The FSR's are awesome. I ordered the FSR kit from: https://www.ultibots.com/fsr-kit/. As far as I can see, this is the best solution for probing on this type of machine.
  6. Firmware.
    I upgraded to Repetier firmware, and really like it. The printer seems much smoother. If you plan to do these upgrades, let me know and i'll upload the correct configuration file.

Notes:
  1. All carriage components in PLA for stiffness.
  2. Effector parts out of whatever is your go-to for high temp resistant material. I made my effector from Aluminum, and printed the Cyclops mount out of Taulman Alloy 910. ABS, PC, etc would be a good choice as well.
  3. Extruder out of your choice - Nylon would be best, I chose PLA to get good detail on the gear set.
    4.FSR mounts out of the same material as the effector - Nylon, PC, ABS, etc.

Good luck, happy printing, and leave a comment if you have any questions.
Fusion360

description.text:
######################ENGLISH#######################
This thing were created by me for home decorating. Unfortunately, i can't print it at this time so i wanted to share this awesome file with you ! It was a scale creation (so at scale 1:1) like the ones in Disneyland Paris, the ones who where in the DCA and probably in the original one too.
If you want to modificate it do it, it was originally pretented to be a Half Dial clock drived by arduino but i give here the normal files
If you want a static one, use "Dial_All_In_One_Static"
If you want to print part by part use "Dial_Numbers" , "Dial_Hand" , "Dial_No_Numbers" and "Dial_FrontCircle"
If you want to make the back of the dial il some kind of yellow, you can cast directly on the model "Dial_No_Numbers_No_Backplates" , and use the "Dial Numbers" , "Dial_Hand" and "Dial_FrontCircle"
It may be easier to use CNC machine to make the biggest part, and 3D print the "Dial-FrontCircle" and the "Dial_Hand" too
Hope you gonna enjoy it
####################################################

#######################FRANCAIS#####################
Lorsque je l'ai créé, je voulais faire une horloge a demi cadran piloté par une arduino. Hors le temps me manque, j'ai ainsi décidé de partager ce projet avec vous !
Il s'agit d'une réplique a l'échelle 1:1, sois a taille réelle qui fais donc 43cm de long !
Ainsi je vous joint les fichier nécessaire a l'impression/ réalisation de cette oeuvre d'art a imprimer et peindre!
Voici les combinaisons possibles :
-Si vous désirez un modèle statique et avez une grande imprimante 3D, "Dial_All_In_One_Static" est parfait pour vous !
-Si vous voulez le modifier et le mécaniser, je vous conseille "Dial_Numbers" , "Dial_Hand" , "Dial_No_Numbers" et "Dial_FrontCircle" , ou si vous désirez supprimer une pièce remplacer "Dial_No_Numbers" et "Dial_Numbers" par "Dial_Normal_Numbers" , ce qui rendra un travail le travail de peinture compliqué, les chiffres n'étant pas de la même couleur que le fond.
-Pour ceux qui veulent refaire la partie en résine derrière, vous pouvez directement verser la résine dans "Dial_No_Numbers_No_Backplates" qui possède le fond vide, puis rajouter "Dial Numbers" , "Dial_Hand" et "Dial_FrontCircle"

Je vous conseille d’ailleurs pour ceux qui peuvent de faire usiner les pièces suivantes avec une fraiseuse CNC dans un bloc de polystyrène extrudé, ça vous coutera moins cher :
-"Dial_No_Numbers_No_Backplates"
-"Dial_No_Numbers"
-"Dial_Normal_Numbers"

En espérant que ça vous plaira ;)
####################################################

description.text:
Hey! Listen!

While working on a separate (but similar) project, I figured I could make something pretty neat with the reference model. However, something terrible happened and all I ended up with was Navi.

I like the idea of being able to print out the wings in one color, the body in another color, and the base in third color. Or you can print it all in the same color. Either way, you still get the two-level effect (with a little path that runs down the middle).

If you're feeling extra adventurous and want to add a tactile enhancement, you can raise the height (in the Z axis) of the round body by about a millimeter or so. This should give it a slight 3D feel. In completed STL (all of it put together), I have raised the body a millimeter for effect.

What I am going to do is print the base in black, the wings in white, and the body in either regular blue or glow-in-the-dark* blue. I have added a second base that has a loop so that you can scale the entire thing down, print it, glue it together, and make it a keychain. Don't know why you'd want Navi on your keys but hey(!), at least this one doesn't make you stop and listen to incredible obvious and garrulous instructions.



**turn out the light and it glows like a real fairy



Reduce it all by 38% for it to be around 2" (50mm) wide if you want it as a keychain.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm (100 microns)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

By default, the base has the following dimensions:

H: 3mm
W: 132.5mm
D: 88mm

...which is quite large. NOT the normal size for a keychain. If you want to make it as a keychain, scale it down to about 38% to end up with it being around 50mm (just under 2") wide.
If your printer isn't calibrated, you may end up with ill-fitting parts. A good sanding should get things to fit if they are a smidge too large.

UPDATE:

  • Slightly more secure hold of controller
  • Controller can be much more comfortable grabbed from the holder
  • Reduce the number of required screws

Let me know what you think :-)

Happy printing!

Top mounted controller holder, designed for the XBOX One (S) Controller. I thought I could use the empty space above my PC case and wanted to securely store my XBOX One S controller readily to hand. The holder can be screwed under a table or a shelf and my One S controller fits in very well.

The first prototype in the pictures is printed in PLA, 200 µm, 15% infill, 2 perimeters, and is very sturdy. I optimized the design to print it without supports. However, the backside of the front part (labeled with "XBOX") shows some fine ripples.

Have fun printing!

To get micro usb ports in the hole, start with one side of the explorer board and pivot the other side in. Once both sides are in, push on the middle of the board to make sure the board is at the proper depth.

Do the same with the lid, start with the side that goes against the divider (as opposed to the outside of the case.Put that in place and pivot the opposite side in before inserting the lid in too far.

To remove lid, use corner cutout and wedge a pocketknife or screwdriver and slowly work your way around the perimeter.

Notes:

This adapter can be printed on the ares3d. However It would be best to print the some of the parts on a larger printer as the ares print area is too small for the Camera Tower.

This thing works with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754003 and adapts it to the EasyArts Ares 4 in 1 3d printer.

author: rabit

title: A box for lock pinning projects

description.text:
UPDATE: Please check out the second version of this box which is much better!

This is a box with a lid for the pins of a lock.
If you are pinning up your own locks then you sometimes need to store the lock disassembled. The most common way to do is is by "storing" the pins on the pinning tray but if it falls or a cat decides to play with it the pins may fall out, change order, or be lost completely. This box has a lid which keeps your pins in proper order safely. It has a simple locking mechanism that snaps into place allowing you to put the box in your pocket if you wish.

title: Knuckle couplers for the 1/32 OpenRailway EMD SW1500
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've designed knuckle couplers that fit the 1/32 EMD SW1500 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:916416).
It wasn't easy as space is scarce but it works.

The hook and tang are cut in 2 so they can be printed without support (when printed with support, the result is too rough to ensure smooth operation).

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed in ABS.
It's important to select a suitable wall thickness to have the springs fully filled (check in the layers display). If the springs are only partially filled they'll be to weak to keep the coupler straight.
With my Prusa I3 MK2 (0.4 mm nozzle) I selected 0.35 mm for the wall thickness and with the Vertex (0.35 mm nozzle) 0.3 mm..

WARNING !

As the SW1500 has a huge overhang,you can't use the coupler on R1 (600mm, 2' radius) tracks. Even on R2 tracks (1200 mm, 3' radius) you'll need to file the opening to widen it a bit or the coupler won't turn enough and the cars will derail.

description.text:
Created with Fusion 360, for 3 time 626 and one 608 bearing.

I printed it using an Ultimaker 2+, and the bearings could be pushed in by hand with a piece of wood or something. This may depend on the printers accuracy and you may have to change the size in your slicer. I took me 3 Iterations to find the right meassurements, so don't worry if it doesn't work first time.

description.text:
Update added a holder for the Smok Alien 220w (16-09-17)
Update is a slight redesign of the battery holder (25-03-17)
Updated with Pictures of the printed desk tidy (25-01-17)

This is a customizable version of my first vape desk tidy. Each of the 4 inserts are removable so if you change your mods you can just pop the insert out and drop a new one back in that holds the mod of your choice.

I have included the 5 inserts that I use. 1 x Kanger subox mod, 1 x Eleaf Aster 75w mod, 1 x Eleaf Istick 60w mod, 1 x Smok Alien 220w mod and a large 35mm atty stand holder.

I have included a blank (30mm high) that can be customized for other mods and a smaller (25mm high) that can be customized for attys or atty stands.

*** If you customize one of the blanks for other mods or attys and want them included send them over and I will include them and credit you with the parts but please do not send other peoples work without consent.****

The first version is here. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1747235

ctc rep dual sailfished

No

Yes

what ever you print at - 0.2 / 0.25

15 - 20 %

Notes:

No rafts are needed unless you print with them. Supports are needed because of the overhang on the 18650 battery holder.

print_settings.Notes:: I used two different materials to make the lid translucent for the LED functionality.

description.text:
The case is for a special USBasp (BAITE) which has a little dip switch for changing voltage!

The lid is meant to be printed in a translucent and the case in an opaque material. You need to glue them together after inserting the device. It should fit and after glueing it should not move inside anymore. Make sure your printer is calibrated very good!

You should choose supports for the front and back holes to print clean.

Note: You can partial cover the translucent area to focus the LED. You could even use an opaque material for the lid and drill two holes to see the LEDs below when the case is closed.

This is my very first design and was made with Fusion360. I am sure I did it "wrong". But I am very proud on my first working and useful design :)

The case is also available at GrabCad

The device can be ordered here: Aliexpress or Amazon Germany

You can also get the Model as Fusion 360 File

ANET A8

No

Yes

0.2 mm

20

The little torus visible in the project near the base signals the point until which the pole should be inserted into the table.

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Module Adapter for Micro Four Thirds Mount.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Adapter for Raspberry Pi Camera Module with M43 Mount

CAUTION:

DO THIS AT YOUR OWN RISK!
This may harm/destroy your Raspberry Pi camera module.

What you need?

Raspberry Pi Camera Module v2 (v1 should be okay but I didn't try.)
Lens or Telescope uses Micro Four ThiCamera Module Lens is attached as a screw. Turn the lens module counter clockwise then you can remove the lens.rds mount.

How to use it

3D Print this thing and do this.
Please refer to pics in "How I Designed This" section, too.

1. Detach Lens from Raspi Camera.

Camera Module Lens is attached as a screw. Detach the lens module by rounding lens counter clockwise. Afterword, I recommend to re-attach the lens loosely so that you can remove it easily when finish.

2. Attach the camera

Put your camera module. See Pictures below.

3. Attach M43 Lens.

Depends on the Lens, you can not adjust focus using lens feature such as focus ring.
In this case, Try Zoom in/out. Or modify this thing as you like.

In my case, attached to my Telescope with M43 T-Adapter.
So far so good.

If you have Pibow case, you can use 2nd STL "Raspberry-Pi-Camera-Module-M43-w-Pibow.stl" to attach Raspberry Pi onto this module.

Designed for my father, this servo mount will allow you to switch a Lego train using an arduino or other hobbyist microcontrollers with a small cheap servo and this servo mount.

This design has been based around the "SG90 Micro Servo 9g" which is widely avaliable from a wide range of retailers.

Note that there is a 'left' and 'right' version of the base to be used accordingly with left and right hand switches.

Assembly

"servoHousingV4Holder" Holds the servo itself, slide the servo into the holder. This is then placed on top of "servoHousingBase". "servoHousingSwitch" is then fitted on the end of the servo's arm to reduce strain on the servo. Clip the whole lot onto the top of your lego switch, keeping the yellow lever attached and positioned in the middle of the "V" shaped part of the servo housing switch part, then add the "servoHousingLid" to finish it all off.
For example code you can check out the following project on Github.

19.01.2017

The switch piece has been updated and now has a small hole for the screw supplied with the servo. See servoHousingV2Switch.stl
servoHousingV1Switch.stl is still avaliable if you would still like it without the hole.

description.text:
This is a mount that I designed to hold my Iphone 6 in order to take time lapses of prints. To hold it to your print bed you need to use bulldog clips or some other kind of clip that is similar. I use 4 on my printer, 1 on each end and then 1 one directly on either side of the phone extension. The extension is held onto the base using 1 inch by 6/32 inch screws and secured using 6/32 inch nuts. The phone rest is help onto the extension the same way. The clamps are secured using a total of 4 1 inch by 6/32 inch screws and 4 6/32 inch nuts.

You will need two of the "phone go pro mount clamp"
You will need one of the "phone go pro mount extension"
You will need one of the "phone go pro mount base"
You will need one of the "phone go pro mount phone rest"

title: Tronxy X3 x-belt tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The acrylic pulley mount for the x-belt left a lot to be desired on my Tronxy X3. The belt rubbed again the edge of the end of the extrusion rubbing of bits of rubber, and warped a bit with the belt a bit off kilter. Not good.

Inspired by Eric Flies design from the Tronxy X3 Facebook group, I created my own solution.

Reuses existing bits. Only needs an M5x25 screw and an M5 nut.

If you find this useful, please encourage me with a tip.

A y-belt tensioner is in the works and being tested.

UPDATE: Changed the print orientation of the shaft part to hopefully ease installation. Modified the end cap with a slightly deeper lip and orientation arrows. Modified the knob to cover the screw end better. Included the new parts in the set.
UPDATE: Added a flatter endcap as a request by Budi.
UPDATE: Added a (hopefully) better design for the X1, but untested.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Printed with 3 wall/perimeters and 5 top and bottom layers. The shaft is printed vertically and uses print discs to help hold to the bed.

Only extra parts need are an M5x25 screw and an M5 nut.

Trim or break off the print pads on the shaft part. They are only used for printing.

Reuse the existing screws and drop-in t-nuts morning them in the two from facing holes. Slide it over the 2020 extrusion.

Thread the M5 screw onto the bracket until it's tight. Reuse the carriage washers, washers, bearing, M5 screw and lock nut and reassemble the pulley in the new bracket. Tighten just enough to hold together.

With over 500 hours on my X3,bits of the belt's edge was worn off ending up in the bearing. I used extra oil to flush out the bearing before reassembly.

You might have snip the zip tie on the right side of the hot end sled to rethread the belt through the new pulley system.

Press an M5 nut into the knob part. I used a locknut, but had to tighten a screw into a few times to loosen it a bit or when you tried to tighten using the knob, it would back the M5x25 out of the bracket.

Once assembled, turn knob to tighten. Don't over do it.

Happy printing.

This is an adapter to fit SteveCKs MicroDamper to allow connection to a BBQ Guru smoker adapter. It slips internally into part Fanhousing_Universal.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1232065

I made a quick modular mount for my installation, worked great for me, need some improvement but it's a first try.
Pretty solid, it allows to ajust on each axis to get the airflow at the right place.

Need some support for one piece (carefull, the inside of the large piece must not have support in it for the air to pass). With Simplify3D it is easy to place support just under the right place, don't know about other slicers.
This is just a quick prototype, i will post something better later.

FR : Pièce faite rapidement pour adapter un ventilateur type 5015 à ma prusa i3 (CTC), extrudeur MK8. Permet d'ajuster dans tous les axes la ventilation pour l'adapter correctement.
Attention, la plus grosse pièce a besoin d'un support, mais pas à l'intérieur de la buse de ventilation, ce qui couperait le flux d'air. Les support sont simples à gérer sous simplify3D, je ne sais pas pour les autres slicers.
Une version retravaillée sera publiée plus tard, il s'agissait surtout ici pour moi d'avoir une pièce fonctionnelle et adaptable, rapidement.

A custom-made 84-tooth ring gear compatible with the VEX EDR robotics design system. This gear may be used in conjunction with VEX gears to create working planetary gearsets

The standard gear is 0.25" thick, intended for the normal-strength VEX gears found in starter and educational robotics kits, and the HS gear is 0.5" thick, compatible with VEX high-strength gears.

A VEX 84-tooth gear will mesh perfectly inside each of these gears. Planetary systems may be created from various combinations of 12-tooth, 36-tooth, and 60-tooth gears.

The EZP versions have smooth undersides to facilitate better print bed adhesion.

These gears are NOT intended for use in the VEX Robotics Competition. They are meant for educational purposes.

description.text:
This thing is a box clasp. The catch and clasp screw onto a wooden box. The clasp grabs the catch and when clicked closed will keep a box closed until the clasp is lifted. The clasp includes textured finger surface and easy to lift opening. The clasp has been designed to cover the mechanism for a discrete and professional looking latch.

This thing is also designed to be printed in a single print with no assembly of the sub-parts required. All moving parts will easily rotate once supports have been removed.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

40%

Notes:

This part is best printed as shown in the .STL and .F3D files. It has been oriented correctly in the model for best printing. You will need to add supports for printing but try to use the least amount of support necessary. I have included a support file for Simplify3d that will give you successful results.

My wife asked me for a blanket box to put under the bed. So I designed the box and then needed some hinges and a lock/clasp. I designed this clasp based on a dog clamp I have in the workshop, to understand the mechanism. There are other similar clasps but they are all open. I thought it would be nice to have closed clasp that is neat and tidy.

author: CamoFPV

title: EASY TO PRINT: Educational 4:1 Gear Ratio Example

description.text:
This is a simple, easy to print model of gear ratios.

There is a stand for the gears, three gears with diameters of 2.5, 5 and 10 centimeters included in the file location. Giving gear ratios of 2:2:1

When assembled these objects have a 4:1 gear ratio. This meaning that for every time the small 2.5cm gear turns four times, the large 10cm gear turns once. Other properties of gears can be observed using this assembly. For example, only the beginning and final gear affect ratio.

Despite this, intermediate gears (the 5cm gear in this case) can serve some purpose. Note how the small and large gear both rotate in the same direction, whilst the middle gear rotates in the opposite direction. Other applications of intermediate gears include reducing torque and transnational loads on the beginning and final gears.

Meshing of gears such as in this model are used to convert speed to the rotational motion known as torque. An application in the real world could be in an electronic linear actuator often used on smaller backhoes to move to move the arm.

If you enjoyed this project of mine stay tuned for a planer example of car transmissions. Or also check out my previous gear prints.

Happy Printing~~

description.text:
I broke my 40mm fan, so I'm using a 50mm radial fan (since I already had one). This is really quiet, and I have measured the bolt nearest the extruder reaching 38C (20C ambient, extruder 260C). This works, if you don't like it, don't make it.

Gives open access to the extruder, no heatsink required.

Version 2 is better, doesn't block X axis motion, and has the fan better centred.
